short_description_en: All-cause mortality for patients with HIV or HCV.
medium_description_en: Estimates risk of 5-year all-cause mortality in patients with HIV and/or HCV.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Aids in prognostication in patients with HIV or Hepatitis C. Potentially useful with goals of care planning or aggressiveness of therapy.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The VACS Index comes from a US VA population, so most patients in both the derivation and validation cohorts were men.
  • Half of patients had started anti-retrovirals prior to 2004, so it is unknown how the newer anti-retrovirals may affect these estimates.
  • <5% of patients in this study were ≥65 years old so this is likely less accurate in older populations.
  • Few patients in the study had significant renal disease: >90% had an eGFR ≥60.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Traditional mortality estimates using only viral load or CD4 count in HIV or FIB-4 in Hepatitis C are inaccurate; the VACS Index looks adds additional markers to estimate multi-organ system involvement and more-accurately predict mortality.

next_steps.critical_actions_en: Because half of the patients in the study had started anti-retrovirals prior to 2004, it is unknown how newer anti-retrovirals may affect the score's estimates. Use clinical judgement when planning care or aggressiveness of therapy.

creator_info.about_en: Amy Justice, MD, PhD, is the CNH Long Professor of Medicine and of Public Health at Yale University and a Staff Physician at the VA Connecticut Healthcare System. As principal investigator of the Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS), she has more than 20 years of experience developing and validating predictive indices using electronic health record data.

seo.meta_description_en: The Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS) Index estimates risk of 5-year all-cause mortality in patients with HIV and/or HCV.
